The exponential distribution

The exponential distribution is defined by\[  f(t)=\lambda e^{-\lambda t}\qquad t\ge 0\qquad \lambda \text{ a constant} \]or sometimes by\[ f(t)=\frac{1}{\mu} e^{- t/\mu}\qquad t\ge 0\qquad \mu \text{ a constant} \]The  advantage of this latter representation is that it may be shown that the mean of the distribution is  \(\mu\).

Example

The lifetime \(T\) (years) of an electronic component is a continuous random variable with a probability density function given by \[ f(t)=e^{-t}\qquad t\ge 0 \qquad (\text{i.e. } \lambda=1 \text{ or } \mu=1)\] Find the lifetime \(L\) which a typical component is \(60\%\) certain to exceed.  If five components are sold to a manufacturer, find the probability that at least one of them will have a lifetime less than \(L\) years.

Solution

We require  \(\text{P}(T>L)=0.6\).  We know that this probability is given by the relationship \[ \text{P}(T>L)=\int_L^{\infty} e^{-t}\,dt=\left[\phantom{\dfrac{1}{1}}\!\!\!-e^{-t}\right]_L^{\infty}=e^{-L}\] Solving \(e^{-L}=0.6\)  for the least value of \(L\) we obtain \(L=0.51\)   years.

Assuming that the lifetime of each component is independent we have \[\text{P} (\text{at least one component has a lifetime less than  0.51 years})\] \[ =1-\text{P} (\text{no component has a lifetime less than  0.51 years})\] \[ =1-0.6^5 =0.92\]
